title: 111_s3753
content:
The "Preventing Unemployment Act of 2010" includes provisions for short-time compensation programs, temporary financing for payments, federal short-time compensation, grants for state programs, assistance in implementation, and reporting requirements. The "Preventing Unemployment Act of 2010" introduces a short-time compensation program where employers can voluntarily reduce work hours instead of laying off employees. Eligible employees with reduced workweeks of at least 10 percent can receive pro rata unemployment compensation. The short-time compensation program allows eligible employees to receive pro rata unemployment compensation while working reduced hours. Employees are not required to meet work search test requirements but must be available for their normal workweek. They can also participate in approved training programs to enhance job skills. Employers must certify continued provision of health and retirement benefits to eligible employees. The short-time compensation program allows eligible employees to receive pro rata unemployment compensation while working reduced hours. Employers must submit a written plan for implementation, ensure union agreement, and comply with National Labor Relations Act. The short-time compensation program allows eligible employees to receive pro rata unemployment compensation while working reduced hours. The amendment to the State law includes provisions determined by the Secretary of Labor for the program's implementation. The effective date of the amendment is upon the enactment of the Act, with a possible delay for states already running a similar program. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow for the withdrawal of amounts for short-time compensation programs. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow for the withdrawal of amounts for short-time compensation programs under specific conditions outlined in the Social Security Act and the Unemployment Compensation Amendments of 1992. The Unemployment Compensation Amendments of 1992 repeal subsections (b) through (d) of section 401. SEC. 3. TEMPORARY FINANCING OF CERTAIN SHORT-TIME COMPENSATION PAYMENTS. Payments to States shall be made equal to 100 percent of short-time compensation paid under a program defined in the Internal Revenue Code. States must meet program requirements to be eligible for payments, including covering additional administrative expenses. Payments to States under this section are reimbursed monthly based on the Secretary's estimates, adjusted for any discrepancies in prior payments. The payment limitations restrict benefits to 26 weeks per individual. No payments shall be made to a State under this section for benefits paid to an individual by the State under a short-time compensation program if the individual is employed by an employer with workforce reductions exceeding 20% in the previous 3 months or on a seasonal, temporary, or intermittent basis. Payments to a State under this section are available for up to 26 weeks of unemployment. Payments under this section are available for weeks of unemployment beginning on or after the enactment of this Act and ending within 3 years. Funding is appropriated from the Treasury for implementation, and the Secretary certifies payments to each State. Definitions include the Secretary of Labor and terms related to State laws. The terms "State agency" and "State law" are defined in the Federal-State Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 1970. SEC. 4. TEMPORARY FEDERAL SHORT-TIME COMPENSATION. Any State may enter into an agreement with the Secretary to participate in a short-time compensation program, provided that the State's law does not already allow for such payments. States can terminate the agreement with 30 days' notice. The agreement with the Secretary can be terminated with written notice. The State agency will make payments under an approved plan for short-time compensation, not exceeding 26 weeks. Individual payments are restricted based on certain criteria. Employers can implement short-time compensation plans for employees who have experienced temporary layoffs or work reductions. The employer must pay the state half of the compensation amount, which will be deposited into the state's unemployment fund. Employers can implement short-time compensation plans for employees, where the state will be reimbursed for half of the compensation paid and any additional administrative expenses incurred. The Secretary may adjust payments to states based on prior estimates, with funding appropriated from the Treasury as needed. The Secretary will certify payments to each state under this section. This agreement applies to the implementation of short-time compensation plans for employees. An agreement under this section applies to weeks of unemployment starting from the agreement date and ending within 2 years of the Act's enactment. If a State enacts a law for short-time compensation, it will not be eligible for payments under this section. Definitions include the Secretary of Labor and terms related to State laws. The terms "State", "State agency", and "State law" are defined in section 205 of the Federal-State Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 1970. SEC. 5. GRANTS FOR IMPLEMENTATION OF STATE SHORT-TIME COMPENSATION PROGRAMS. The Secretary will award start-up grants to State agencies that enact short-time compensation programs on or after May 1, 2010, and apply for the grants by September 30, 2012. The grant amount will be determined based on program implementation costs, with each State agency eligible for only one grant. Funding for implementing short-time compensation programs will be appropriated from the Treasury. The Secretary may establish reporting requirements for State agencies receiving grants to oversee fund usage. Definitions include the Secretary of Labor and terms from the Federal-State Extended Unemployment Compensation Act. The Secretary of Labor will assist States in establishing short-time compensation programs by developing model legislative language, providing technical assistance, and establishing reporting requirements on averted layoffs, participating companies, and workers. SEC. 7. REPORTS.

The Secretary of Labor will submit reports to Congress and the President on the implementation of short-time compensation programs, including analysis of impediments to State enactment. Additional reports may be submitted as deemed necessary. $1,500,000 is appropriated for this purpose.
